0.00.text:
Translator: Mercia Costa
Reviewer: Denise RQ

19.79.text:
I've invested a lot of my own money
into organic and sustainable farming,

25.30.text:
and to converting
American farmland to organic,

27.79.text:
and I'm here to dispel
some misperceptions about organic food.

33.96.text:
that organic farming is more expensive
and less sufficient, right?

38.18.text:
And that we need industrial agriculture
and factory farms to feed the world.

43.57.text:
Well, I'm here to dissect
some of the assumptions behind that logic,

47.17.text:
and to share some information
that leads to a very different conclusion.

51.03.text: We all know organic food is expensive.

55.66.text:
And it's logical to therefore assume
that it's for the 1%, the foodie elites,

61.08.text: the rich people, not for ordinary people.

63.95.text:
Well, that's actually not correct logic,
and I will show why in a second.

67.58.text:
It also leads us to assume
that if organic food is expensive,

70.76.text:
organic farming must be more expensive,
which then leads to wonder,

74.24.text: surely, it can't feed the world,

77.01.text:
and back to concluding
that it's only for the 1%.

81.69.text:
Well, those assumptions
actually are wrong as well.

84.36.text:
The idea that organic food
is only for the rich,

87.87.text: only for the 1% is a powerful one,

90.27.text:
with huge implications
on both business and policy.

94.52.text: And we need both business innovation

97.07.text:
and policy change in this country
to support organic.

100.59.text:
Think about it, if you are
a business person or a politician,

103.98.text:
the way to be successful
is to come up with products or policies

107.42.text:
that cater not to the 1%
but to ordinary Americans.

112.25.text:
And so we need businessmen
and policy makers to recognize

116.47.text: that organic food is not just for the 1%,

119.54.text:
it's for everybody,
it's for ordinary Americans.

122.76.text:
And the first step in that change
is to change that perception.

126.00.text:
So, who is buying
this expensive organic food?

129.66.text: Who in America is buying it?

131.71.text: According to Nielsen and NMI research,

134.75.text:
three out of every four Americans
have consciously chosen

137.73.text: to buy organic food in the past year.

140.12.text:
Some of them might have only bought
a single organic product,

143.64.text:
but there is a subset that there are
the so-called devoted organic shoppers,

147.74.text:
that represent the vast majority of all
organic food consumption in this country.

156.50.text:
they are 25%, one out
of every four Americans.

159.96.text: Now let's look at these elite foodies.

161.97.text: What does the elite foodie look like?

164.49.text:
Two out of five of them have
an annual household income

168.78.text:
One out of five has
an annual household income

173.26.text:
These elite people are about
20% people of color,

179.90.text: Six out of ten of them shop at Walmart.

182.48.text:
How does that profile compare
to the general U.S. population?

189.10.text:
The general U.S. population is about
two out of five income less than 50K,

193.97.text: one out of five income less than 30K.

196.38.text:
About 20% people of color, 15% Hispanic,
and about six out of ten shop at Walmart.

203.21.text:
the foodie elite who are buying organic
are the average ordinary American.

209.92.text: And it's one out of four Americans,

212.27.text:
and they're already buying organic
in spite of how expensive it is.

216.17.text:
Just imagine how many more Americans
would be buying organic food

219.31.text: if it wasn't so damn expensive.

221.53.text:
Well, we actually know
some of the answers to that.

227.00.text:
and found that 91% of them
would be buying organic.

231.02.text: So, why is organic food so darn expensive?

234.49.text:
It must be because organic farming
is more expensive, right?

238.51.text:
Not true; organic farming
actually saves a ton of money

241.48.text: on a lot of very expensive inputs.

248.00.text:
The chemicals, the antibiotics
that are used by factory farms.

255.85.text:
but their actual dollar
costs are very high.

258.40.text:
Well, so maybe organic farming saves money
but perhaps it produces less food.

265.81.text:
This is not a blanket statement,
it varies by crop and region,

269.37.text:
but there are lot of ways
in which, when done right,

272.37.text:
organic sustainable farming
can produce more food.

276.22.text:
One part of that is crop
and livestock rotations,

279.24.text:
so that nutrients
are recycled into the soil.

282.51.text:
Growing multiple crops at the same time,
increasing the revenue of the land.

289.48.text:
One of my favorites examples
of this is sheep and asparagus.

293.00.text:
Sheep love to graze but they do not like
the taste of asparagus.

297.73.text:
And so, when the asparagus farmer
has a weed problem,

302.24.text: rather than spending a lot of money

303.94.text:
buying a chemical herbicide
to spray in the fields,

306.70.text: they can invite in a sheep farmer.

308.89.text: The sheep will clear the weeds.

311.01.text:
The sheep farmer gets free pasture
for his or her animals,

315.51.text:
and the asparagus farmer
gets free weed control.

319.05.text: And, the sheep add fertility to the soil.

324.33.text:
but industrial agriculture,
for all of its ills,

326.97.text:
surely at least the one thing it has
is that it's more efficient, right?"

330.62.text:
I would say that it has
the illusion of efficiency,

335.54.text: For example, think about the topsoil.

339.63.text:
perhaps the single, greatest
national treasure this country possesses,

343.32.text:
this rich topsoil, is like a bank account
that we're drawing on every year.

347.76.text:
Withdrawing money
and not putting it back in.

354.61.text: Similarly, the way we treat nutrients.

356.76.text:
Nutrients are supposed
to come from the soil,

359.00.text:
go through the body of a plant,
into the body of an animal,

363.00.text: We all learned that in high school.

364.75.text:
And that's not how the vast majority of
North American agriculture works today.

368.59.text:
Instead, we're mining minerals in Morroco,
shipping them across the Atlantic,

374.58.text:
only to have them wash off
into the waterways,

377.10.text:
and end up in dead zones,
and places like the Gulf of Mexico.

380.48.text:
That's not efficient,
it's incredibly wasteful.

386.63.text:
Similarly, what I said earlier
about fossil fuels,

389.51.text:
antibiotics to feed
the factory farm animals.

392.49.text:
And all of this to increase
the yield of corn and soy.

397.36.text: Crops that humans don't even actually eat.

400.99.text:
We're maximizing
the yield per acre of corn and soy,

403.96.text:
yet the vast majority of American farmland
does not feed humans.

408.29.text:
It's either used to create ethanol
or to feed livestock.

413.04.text:
About less than 10%
of the corn crop in this country

418.94.text:
This is the system
that is supposed to feed the world?

422.13.text:
Well, it's actually
not feeding the world today.

425.07.text:
If you measure, the right way
to measure productivity in agriculture

428.58.text:
is not the yield of corn per acre
or soy per acre,

431.50.text: but the yield of human food per acre.

434.51.text:
And when you measure how much
human food is produced per acre,

443.52.text:
and we're behind countries
like India and China,

446.00.text:
that are making a much better job of
feeding the world population than we are.

450.90.text:
So, if you were smart, you would realize
what's really behind that status

455.49.text:
is the fact that these other countries
consume less meat that America does.

459.50.text:
And, so, who is going to produce all
the increasing appetite for pork in China,

464.38.text:
And surely, American industrial
agriculture and factory farms

468.76.text:
are going to step forward
to supply all the meat.

472.21.text: Well, I'm not sure that's true either.

474.25.text:
The leading exporter of pork
in the world today is Denmark.

478.56.text:
Denmark is a country
that has for many years banned

481.23.text:
the use of sub-therapeutic
antibiotics in livestock.

484.50.text:
One of the most disgusting and reckless
practices of American factory farms

490.91.text:
yet Denmark has continued to maintain
high yields and low prices for their pork,

495.44.text:
and is the number one exporter
of pork to places like China.

499.50.text:
Ironically, China has
recently banned pork imports

503.02.text:
from several U.S. pork producers
because of the use of antibiotics.

509.21.text:
What's the most efficient way
to produce food

511.31.text: if people are going to eat more meat?

513.24.text: Well, if you look at one acre of corn,

516.44.text:
it can produce about enough corn
to feed one head of cattle.

520.18.text:
This is an approximation,
this is not very exact math.

522.91.text:
That same acre-I wouldn't advocate
planting organic corn to feed the cattle -

527.80.text:
that same acre can produce about
enough grass to feed one head of cattle.

533.99.text: Now, it's not an exact math.

537.59.text:
and there is a lot of other things
that change the equation.

540.51.text:
Corn is a more efficient crop
in a lot of ways.

542.77.text:
It's a wonderful crop,
it allows for a lot more control,

547.85.text:
but it also has a lot of other costs
on the balance sheet.

550.96.text:
At the end of the day,
it's not a slam dunk

553.90.text:
that industrial agriculture is
more efficient, even for producing meat.

557.89.text:
Now, the truly more efficient way
to feed humans is to use that land

562.57.text: to produce crops that people eat,

565.00.text: like fruits, vegetables, wheat or rice.

568.09.text:
But the benefit of growing
meat on pasture

571.24.text:
is at least those animals
fertilize the land,

575.12.text:
and if you do a rotation between
those animals and fruits and vegetables,

579.89.text:
you can actually produce
more off that same land.

582.37.text: It must be about the money then, right?

584.38.text:
These so called evil corporations
like McDonald's and Monsanto.

588.50.text:
Perhaps they are shoving
this industrial food down our throats

593.73.text: Well, that's actually not true either.

595.75.text:
In fact, using the techniques
I just described, Farmland LP,

600.45.text: - which I'm a very large investor in -

602.35.text:
converts farms
from conventional crops to organic,

608.27.text: They've done a cohort analysis of farmland

612.53.text:
that they've been progressively
converting to organic,

615.37.text:
and in doing so, significantly
raising the income from the land,

618.62.text:
from something like 100 dollars
to 450 dollars per acre.

623.40.text:
You might think: "Well, that's great
but perhaps it can't scale."

627.63.text:
Well, the answer is actually organic
and sustainable agriculture is scaling.

633.74.text:
which is the closest we have
to a fast food organic company,

636.98.text:
is the single fastest growing
fast-food company of the past decade.

640.25.text:
And, more broadly, organic cropland
in the U.S. has grown tremendously,

644.86.text:
more than tripling
in less than two decades.

647.81.text:
So, organic saves money,
is less expensive,

651.72.text:
can produce as much or more food,
is more profitable, and is scaling.

657.13.text:
Then, what the... why the heck
is organic food so expensive?

663.28.text:
And the answer is because the demand
for organic food is growing even faster.

668.98.text:
That graph of organic cropland growing
is still a drop in the bucket,

673.27.text:
and it pales compared
to the surge in demand

676.49.text:
for organic sustainable food
in this country.

678.99.text:
The total amount
of organic cropland in America

682.16.text:
is about 1% of this country's
agricultural land.

685.51.text:
The total amount
of consumption of organic food

689.96.text:
and that does not even
reflect the total demand.

692.51.text:
That's how much has actually
been consumed.

695.75.text:
One out of every four Americans
is a devoted organic shopper,

702.79.text:
they would be interested
in buying organic food.

705.10.text:
The demand that we need
to satisfy is not just that 5%.

708.27.text:
But you might wonder
where is that 4 or 5%

710.51.text:
of organic food coming from
if not from our cropland?

716.08.text:
And where is organic food
growing on this planet?

720.76.text:
80% of the certified organic farmers
are in developing countries.

725.55.text:
The country with the most
organic farmers is actually India.

728.61.text:
So, the poor countries
of the world are feeding the food

734.21.text:
that the majority
of want to eat.

738.00.text:
So, I think America should stop worrying
so much about feeding the world,

741.47.text:
and focus a little bit more
on feeding itself.

743.65.text:
The solution to this
is actually relatively simple.

746.75.text:
We need organic sustainably
managed cropland in this country

750.96.text:
to increase dramatically,
to catch up with the enormous demand.

754.97.text: I put my own money where my mouth is,

757.17.text:
and I've invested a lot of money
in Farmland LP as I mentioned,

760.27.text: which is converting land to organic,

762.50.text:
and I think we need both policy change,
and more business innovation

765.80.text:
to accelerate the expansion of sustainable
organic agriculture in America.
